utterances: Barbie, yep.

Well, let's go to Eric Deggans.
Eric, we're going to talk about a show on Netflix.
It's called ""Turn Up Charlie."" And this is Idris Elba - right?
- who is People magazine's sexiest man alive.
(Laughter).
But it sounds like he's...
That's right.
...Playing a bit of a loser here.
Can he pull that off?
That's the question.
So this is Idris playing a down-on-his-luck DJ who's best friend from school turned out to be a huge movie star and married a woman who is a really popular DJ and music producer.
And he winds up in this situation where he winds up watching their bratty kid in exchange for maybe them helping him with his career.
And normally, this is the kind of show that I would absolutely hate, especially if it was something that was done on, like, a sitcom.
Why would you normally hate it?
I would normally hate it because it's kind of formulaic.
And it's unrealistic.
OK.
And it's also weird to take the most famous person in the show and have him play a loser who is the not famous person.
(LAUGHTER)
As a viewer, there's a dissonance there where you're constantly looking at Idris, but he's playing a loser who nobody knows.
But you get a sense that his character is how Idris might have turned out if things hadn't gone so well for him.
He's actually a DJ.
He's performing at Coachella this year.
And if things hadn't worked out so well for him on ""The Wire"" and in his acting roles, maybe he would have been this guy.
Oh, interesting.
You almost - you feel an actor on a personal exploration of a different side of them.
Exactly.
And I love the relationship that he has with his aunt, who's an immigrant, and his best friend.
And I queued up a little interaction between them where he's arguing with his aunt Lydia about whether or not he should even take this job watching this kid.
(SOUNDBITE OF TV SHOW, ""TURN UP CHARLIE"")
(As Lydia) So how are you going to take care of a little girl?
(As Charlie) Well, I'm just keeping an eye on her while they settle in.
That's it.
(As Del) Because you're the nanny.
(As Charlie) No, I'm not the nanny.
I'm just helping out some mates while - and they're going to help me out.
I jump on the mic.
She loves it - No. 1 hit - bang.
So I just liked seeing a different side of Idris Elba.
As you can tell, he's not necessarily cracking jokes.
He's playing this character pretty much the way he would play any character.
But because the situation is so absurd, there's a humor that comes through.
And I particularly like the characters.
OK.
